entry.title: Newsletter #109
entry.content:
Yo folks!

This week we bid farewell to one of our team member Nitesh, he posted an interesting summary of his delightful journey at Namshi, we wish him best of luck.

Below you can find the usual list of interesting articles we discovered in the past 7 days.

  • is it realistic to go from 0 coding experience to freelance developer in 6 months of full time study? – quora

  • what frustrates beginner programmers the most? – quora

  • a cartoon guide to flux — medium

  • bro: just get to the point!

  • coding interview preparation made easy

  • computer science courses that don’t exist, but should

  • docker container for react native android development

  • dockerfiles considered harmful

  • f8 2015 – big code: developer infrastructure at facebook’s scale – youtube

  • full-stack redux tutorial

  • getify/you-dont-know-js

  • getting started with bem (with a little help from sass)

  • hacker way: facebook’s high performance server infrastructure – youtube

  • hoist is how you integrate – meet the microservices platform that talks to apis

  • how docker helped me love writing css again — meedan updates — medium

  • how we designed the new salesforce at scale

  • hubot newrelic

  • is it possible for a computer to run code that could absolutely destroy the components inside (cooking the cpu, etc.)?

  • is it possible for a computer to run code that could absolutely destroy the components inside (cooking the cpu, etc.)?

  • kerning 2015 – oliver reichenstein – architecting information on vimeo

  • kris jenkins' blog (javascript, elm, clojure, vim)

  • launching a product, in just 3652 days

  • lovefield is a relational database for web apps.

  • one weird trick to write better code · evan todd

  • one weird trick to write better code

  • pulling git into a docker image without leaving ssh keys behind

  • putting react in your react native webview so you can react while you react

  • react.js and dynamic children – why the keys are important – arkency blog

  • real-time resizing of flickr images using gpus

  • redux for reactr

  • restful apis, the big lie

  • stop using tail -f (mostly)

  • tech overkill destroyed the loveliest, liveliest city on the west coast

  • the motivation for a monolithic codebase

  • the netflix tech blog: making netflix.com faster

  • value objects in symfony forms – webmozart.io

  • want to learn javascript in 2015?

  • welcome to the code galaxies, commander

  • what feature of c is used very often by experienced programmers but not so much by a newbie? – quora

  • what’s new in chrome devtools?

  • why i don’t shield my team from bad news

  • why i f#!@ing hate unicorns and the culture they breed

entry.title: Newsletter #50
entry.content:
Hey folks! Hope you had a great week!

Announcement:

We are looking for a senior software engineer passionate about NodeJS and a frontend designer who is passionate and kick-ass in CSS and HTML and wants to expand his skillset with some JavaScript — we <3 javascript :)

We will detail in a separate post but, for the time being, feel free to reach out to submit your linkedin / github profile to work-in-tech@namshi.com

Here are your links for this week!

  • Mind-blowing facts about Google
  • Is TLS Fast Yet?
  • Amazon RDS Now Supports T2 Instances
  • The One Big Thing That Will Reduce Software Bugs, But No One Does It
  • CoreOS and Docker through Deis: Your Paas. Your Rules.
  • The Twelve-Factor App
  • Redis 3.0.0 beta 8 is out
  • Critiquing Facebook’s new #PHP spec
  • ideavim – plugin that let’s you use vim keybindings inside a intellj based ides (phpstorm/webstorm ide
  • A very old post, but still super good, about object oriented programming in JavaScript
  • Why does windows think that my wireless keyboard is a toaster
  • Game of Hacks
  • Why I think having passion as a developer matters
  • BadUSB what if you could never trust a USB device again
  • 3 security mistakes small companies make and how to avoid them
  • Track and Audit shipments for free
  • DConf 2014: Declarative programming in D by Mihails Strasuns aka Dicebot
  • Welcome to RocksDB!
  • Alerting Dashboard for Graphite
  • Why You Can’t Learn To Code Without Open Source
  • JavaScript Promises Are Cool
  • The Top Programming Languages in IEEE Spectrum’s 2014 Ranking
  • Building a Better PHP – Part 5: Static Analysis & other CLI tools
  • dotScale 2014 – Fabien Potencier – My Take on PHP
